How Linux has Changed My Life, so far

I find myself once again thinking about Linux. I never thought this would happen to me.

The Push Away from Apple

I was a Mac guy from ~2011-2024. And not just a casual user - I was the type of guy to give presentations at work about how you could use your Mac more effectively. I knew all the good software, I produced videos on a now unlisted YouTube channel about my favorite tips, tricks, and software, and used it daily. I found that the Mac was an excellent development platform. I was comfortable on the platform, and it worked seamlessly with my other Apple devices.

I came to Linux very slowly, then all at once.

I became a fan of Apple around 2010 when Steve Jobs really started to enter my consciousness. I remeber seeing a few of his keynotes live and I thought he was extraordinary, and by extension, so was the company he helped build. Even after his death in 2011, I remained a fan of the company, but my attitude slowly changed from fan to casual observer, then to neutral customer. I liked that I didn't have to worry about Apple "selling my data". Their business model was to make great hardware and convince me to buy it. They were very good at that because they make excellent hardware!

What really soured me on Apple was their treatment of developers. Even though I am not an Apple developer myself, I do consider myself a supporter of small business. Apple's 30% cut of nearly all economic activity that occurs on their platform eventually became inexcusable.

I was fine with the iPhone being locked down (even though I was very much a jailbreaker), I don't like the direction that Apple is taking on the Mac platform. It has slowly become more locked down and more naggy.

On their own, these reasons weren't enough to make me switch. They were annoyances, sure, but with Apple's excellent hardware, nearly bug-free OS, and selection of botique apps, I was still willing to stay.

The Pull Towards Linux

As I transitioned from Product Manager to Software Engineer, my interest in operating systems returned. I always knew that Linux was out there as an option, but it was really only for the die-hard crazy zealots, of course. macOS was the sane option, Windows was the Excel-head option, and Linux was for the freaks.

As someone who was now much more invested in learning how computers work under the hood, I slowly came around to the idea of Linux.

I had installed Ubuntu on one of my machines as a small child only to find that my WiFi card didn't work out of the box. With my only accessible devices being unable to connect to the internet, I bailed and re-installed Windows.
